ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course moved away from textbook "prepared" Latin and drops you into the original text. We started with reading Sallust prose and eventually shifted to Petronius after the thanksgiving break. Picked up lots of more subtle grammar and relied on knowledge from L2 that included indirects and other common grammar conventions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great teacher, bad initial book selection (although not the teachers fault).

Strength: instructor was engaging and we reviewed text in class
Weakness: Instructor moved quickly, easy to fall behind at times and relied on classmates to get caught back up. Weekly quizzes covered high level translation and more minute grammar points that were easy to miss in class.

Sallust was incredibly hard and difficult to translate, but Petronius was much better. The quizzes were also unnecessarily hard and asked some very obscure questions. John Dillon's grading is not the clearest or the most generous, but he was an amazing instructor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: L3 is required so you really don't have a choice. Consider the texts carefully for each section and figure out what you find easier or more enjoyable to read. You'll be doing it all term.
Not really. L5 is actually easier, so if you're on the fence, just take L5
